div1.p: Emilie Lawrence Reed thanks Kelly for his biography of Walter Reed. She is highly complimentary.

div1.head: Letter from Emilie Lawrence Reed to Howard A. Kelly, June 19, 1906
div1.p:
How can I express
to you the mingled feel-
ings of gratitude, pleasure
and pride that “The Life”
has given me- I have
been absorbed either in
its perusal or thoughts
of it ever since its ar-
rival Sunday noon.
So many emotions fill
me for in your delinea-
tion of the beautiful traits
of his character you
have caught the charm
of his personality and
it weaves its “aura” as
a golden thread through-
out the roof of the
whole Life-

You have caused
me in this short span
of time to live over
as in a dream my whole
wedded life, joys and
sorrows blended together in
a most realistic manner-
And you have taught me
that the high pedestal
upon which I had placed
my idol was none too high
to do him honor-

you speak of him as “a great
and good man” and will
you allow me to say that my
heart pours out all of its thanks
and gratitude to an equally
great and good man, who is
sending out to the world this
beautiful tribute to the memory
of my husband.

That this tribute may teach the world
to appreciate his work and add
one leaf to the laurels that are
already gound is the earnest
prayer of one who holds you
in the greatest reverence and
affection- Again with much
gratitude,
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, Emilie Lawrence Reed June 19th '06-
